TEXT: CARDINAL . The present case relates to the issue of “ old ” foreign - currency deposits ( foreign currency deposited before the dissolution of ORG – “ the SFRY ” ) .

CARDINAL . Until the DATE economic reforms ( the so - called ORG reforms , named after the then Prime Minister PERSON ) , the commercial banking system of the SFRY consisted of self - managed basic and associated banks . Basic banks , founded and nominally controlled by socially owned enterprises , carried on day - to - DATE commercial banking activities . CARDINAL or more basic banks could form an associated bank through a self - management agreement , while preserving their legal personality . CARDINAL . Hard - pressed for hard currency as it was , the SFRY made it attractive for its expatriate workers and other citizens to deposit their foreign currency with commercial banks based in the SFRY : such deposits earned high interest ( the DATE interest rate often exceeded PERCENT ) and were guaranteed by ORG see , for example , section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of ORG DATE and section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the PERSON and Other Financial Institutions Act DATE ) .

CARDINAL . The Foreign - Currency Transactions Act DATE introduced a system for redepositing of foreign currency by commercial banks with ORG . Although the system was optional , it allowed commercial banks to shift the currency risk to the ORG and practically all foreign currency was thus redeposited . In addition , ORG was required to grant national - currency loans ( initially , interest - free ) to commercial banks to the value of the redeposited foreign currency . It should be underlined , however , that such redepositing was as a rule only a paper transaction , because commercial banks had insufficient liquid funds : it would appear that commercial banks redeposited in total MONEY ( ORG ) , out of which MONEY ( PERCENT ) was actually transferred to ORG ( see PERSON and Others v. In DATE the system of redeposits was brought to an end ( see section CARDINAL of ORG DATE , as amended on DATE ) .

CARDINAL . Problems resulting from the foreign and domestic debt of the SFRY caused a monetary crisis in DATE . The national economy was on the verge of collapse and the SFRY resorted to emergency measures , such as statutory restrictions on the repayment of foreign - currency deposits ( see section CARDINAL of ORG DATE ) . As a result , foreign - currency deposits were practically frozen .

CARDINAL . Within the framework of the ORG reforms , the SFRY abolished the system of basic and associated banks described above . This shift in the banking regulations allowed some basic banks to opt for an independent status , while other basic banks became branches ( without legal personality ) of the associated banks to which they had beforehand belonged .

CARDINAL . NORP Some important features of the banking system remained , however , unaffected by the reforms . First of all , commercial banks remained under the regime of “ social ownership ” – a concept which , while it does exist in other countries , was particularly highly developed in the SFRY . Secondly , both commercial banks and the ORG had financial obligations arising from foreign - currency savings : depositors were entitled to collect their deposits at any time , together with accumulated interest , from commercial banks ( see sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of LAW DATE ) or , in the event of a commercial bank 's “ manifest insolvency ” or bankruptcy , from the State ( see sections CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) and CARDINAL ) of LAW DATE , section CARDINAL of the Banks and Other Financial Institutions Insolvency Act DATE and a decision of ORG of DATE ) .
CARDINAL . In DATE the SFRY ceased to exist . It was replaced by CARDINAL successor GPE : GPE , GPE , GPE ( succeeded in DATE by GPE ) , “ the former GPE ” and GPE .

CARDINAL . A brutal war started in GPE shortly after its declaration of independence . During the war , GPE took over the statutory guarantee for “ old ” foreign - currency savings from the SFRY ( pursuant to section CARDINAL of LAW DATE ) . Furthermore , the concept of “ social ownership ” was abandoned ( see LAW DATE and ORG DATE ) . As a result , all commercial banks based in GPE were effectively nationalised . While the use of “ old ” foreign - currency savings was allowed in some exceptional situations during the war , it would appear that this possibility remained only theoretical ( see a decision of the Presidency of GPE of DATE and a decision of ORG of DATE ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE the General Framework Agreement for Peace in GPE ( “ the GPE Peace Agreement ” ) entered into force . It confirmed the continuation of the legal existence of GPE as a ORG , while modifying its internal structure ( LAW to ORG , named LAW of GPE ” ) . In accordance with LAW , GPE and GPE consists of QUANTITY Entities : ORG and PERSON . ORG failed to resolve ORG in the GPE area , but the parties agreed to a binding arbitration in this regard under ORG rules ( LAW to ORG ) . Meanwhile , the rural parts of the pre - war GPE municipality remained under the control of ORG and the town of GPE under the control of ORG . An arbitral tribunal issued its final award on DATE . It suspended the legal authority of the ORG within the whole territory of the pre - war GPE municipality and transferred all of the Entity powers to the newly - created GPE under the exclusive sovereignty of GPE and international supervision . GPE was formally inaugurated on DATE . Nevertheless , Entity legislation continued to apply in the District until modified by the Supervisor of GPE or ORG . All Entity legislation ceased to have legal effect in LOC DATE .
